titlestmt.subtitle: A Finding Aid to the Collection in the Library of Congress
titlestmt.author: Prepared by Donna Ellis with the assistance of Dan Oleksiw

profiledesc.creation: Finding aid encoded by Library of Congress Manuscript Division, 2005

did.head: Collection Summary
did.abstract: Radio and television journalist. Appointment books, awards, radio, television, and film scripts, speeches, writings, and research material pertaining to Agronsky's career as a radio and television journalist.

note.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the Library's online catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject or location, and by occupation and listed alphabetically therein.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The papers of Martin Agronsky, radio and television journalist, were given to the Library of Congress by his estate in 2001. Additional material was given in 2003 by David Agronsky.

separatedmaterial.head: Transfers
separatedmaterial.p: Sound recordings, videocassettes, and a film have been transferred to the Motion Picture, Broadcasting, and Recorded Sound Division where they are identified as part of the Martin Agronsky Papers.

userestrict.head: Copyright Status
userestrict.p: Copyright in the unpublished writings of Martin Agronsky in these papers and in other collections in the custody of the Library of Congress is reserved. Consult a reference librarian in the Manuscript Division for further information.

accessrestrict.head: Access and Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: The papers of Martin Agronsky are open to research. Researchers are advised to contact the Manuscript Reading Room prior to visiting. Many collections are stored off-site and advance notice is needed to retrieve these items for research use.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information: Container number, Martin Agronsky Papers, Manuscript Division, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

chronitem.event: B.A., Rutgers University, New Brunswick, N.J.
Correspondent, American Broadcasting Co., Washington, D.C.
Bureau chief, Paris, France, and moderator of “Face the Nation,” Columbia Broadcasting System
Host, “Agronsky and Company,” WETA-TV, Washington, D.C.
Host, “Martin Agronsky's Evening Edition” and “Agronsky at Large,” Public Broadcasting System

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The papers of Martin Agronsky (1915-1999) span the years 1907-1999, with the bulk of the material dating from 1940 to 1990. The papers are organized in the following series: Correspondence, Speeches and Writings File, and a Miscellany consisting primarily of appointment books, awards, biographical material, and items related to organizations with which Agronsky was associated.

The Correspondence series contains primarily letters written by colleagues and the public to Agronsky in response to his newscasts. Incoming and outgoing letters and telegrams document communications between Agronsky and his network supervisors regarding news assignments.

The Speeches and Writings File, especially the scripts of Agronsky's newscasts, forms the centerpiece of the papers. The material dates from his career as a foreign correspondent in Europe, Australia, and Asia during World War II and continues through the Cold War years. His coverage of the Adolf Eichmann trial in Israel won him the Alfred I. DuPont Award in 1962. Other scripts include his work on documentary films. The speech file contains correspondence, notes, and texts pertaining to his lectures on political and economic subjects. Research material includes news clippings, notes, and printed matter relating to the subjects on which Agronsky frequently lectured.

arrangement.head: Organization of the Papers
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged in three series:

scopecontent.p: Correspondence and memoranda between Agronsky and his friends, colleagues, and the public relating to professional activities.
Broadcast and film scripts, magazine articles, research material, and speeches.

arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by type of material and therein chronologically.

did.unittitle: And One to Grow On, 1979-1980, undated
Fact sheets and news releases, 1960-1961, undated
National Endowment for the Arts, 1976, undated
Post World War II economy, 1949-1954, undated

scopecontent.p: Appointment books, awards, biographical material, lawsuits, and correspondence relating to organizations and television programs.
Arranged alphabetically by type of material.

arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by type of material and therein chronologically.
